items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek’s AI chatbot app has achieved significant popularity, ranking at the top of both the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.
- Founded in 2023 by High-Flyer Capital Management, DeepSeek specializes in efficient AI model development.
- The company unveiled DeepSeek-V2 and DeepSeek-V3 models, which are known for low operational costs and competitive performance compared to other models.
- DeepSeek’s products have driven rivals like ByteDance and Alibaba to adjust their pricing strategies.
- The AI models, including the reasoning model R1, face regulatory scrutiny in China that restricts certain topics in responses.
- Microsoft has integrated DeepSeek’s models into its Azure AI Foundry service, influencing AI infrastructure investment strategies across companies.
- Despite its success, DeepSeek faces bans and restrictions from various governments and companies due to national security concerns.
- The future of DeepSeek remains uncertain, especially with potential U.S. government actions against its use.

items.title: What to know about TikTok’s uncertain future in the US and the people who want to buy it
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- TikTok, owned by ByteDance, faces controversy over user data security concerns in the U.S.
- In February 2025, TikTok briefly withdrew from the U.S. App Store and Google Play before returning.
- Valuation estimates for TikTok's U.S. business are upwards of $60 billion amid competing investor interests.
- Significant events include Trump’s 2020 executive order aimed to ban TikTok, leading to legal battles, especially during the Biden administration.
- The U.S. Supreme Court upheld the TikTok ban, while Trump recently expressed a desire to find a solution to keep the app in the U.S.
- Various groups, including The People’s Bid led by Frank McCourt and a consortium led by Jesse Tinsley, are potential buyers of TikTok.

items.title: iPhone and Android users will soon be able to send encrypted RCS messages to each other
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Text messages between iPhones and Android devices will soon have end-to-end encryption (E2EE).
- The GSMA published new specifications for the RCS protocol to support cross-platform E2EE.
- RCS provides features like group messaging and read receipts, similar to WhatsApp.
- Apple is now including RCS support, following the introduction of iOS 18.
- The new E2EE mechanism is based on the Messaging Layer Security (MLS) protocol.
- RCS will be the first large-scale messaging service to offer interoperable E2EE between different platforms.

items.title: Developer of Lockbit ransomware gets extradited to the United States
items.summary:
- Rostislav Panev, a 51-year-old dual Russian-Israeli national, extradited from Israel to the U.S.
- Accused of being a key developer for the LockBit ransomware gang since its inception in 2019.
- Arrested in December 2024 and has been awaiting extradition since then.
- Prosecutors allege Panev designed the ransomware and maintained its infrastructure alongside criminal affiliates.
- U.S. Attorney John Giordano stated that members of the LockBit conspiracy will be pursued.

items.title: US lawmakers urge UK spy court to hold Apple ‘backdoor’ secret hearing in public
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Bipartisan U.S. lawmakers demand an open hearing regarding Apple's challenge to a secret U.K. government order.
- Senator Ron Wyden and others emphasized the public interest in transparency during the hearings.
- The U.K. government secretly ordered Apple to create a backdoor for accessing user data, which Apple refused, opting instead to remove certain encryption features from its services in the U.K.
- The Investigatory Powers Tribunal is set to address a private petition related to this case shortly.

items.title: Kerry Washington invests in wedding marketplace Cheersy
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Kerry Washington leads a pre-seed investment round in the wedding marketplace Cheersy, founded by Amy Shack Egan in 2024.
- Cheersy focuses on connecting couples with day-of wedding coordinators and has raised a total of $550,000 from notable investors, including Christina Tosi and Jennifer Gilbert.
- Shack Egan aims to enhance the Cheersy platform and expand it to six new cities, leveraging her background in wedding planning and addressing the high demand for coordination services.

items.title: UK’s secret iCloud backdoor order triggers civil rights challenge
items.summary:
- The U.K. government issued a secret order to Apple for a backdoor to its end-to-end encrypted iCloud storage service.
- Civil rights groups, Liberty and Privacy International, filed complaints challenging the order, calling it “unacceptable and disproportionate.”
- The Technical Capability Notice (TCN) is believed to affect not only U.K. users but also non-U.K. users, raising concerns about global consequences.
- Apple is appealing the TCN in the Investigatory Powers Tribunal (IPT), with a hearing scheduled for March 14, 2025.
- The civil rights groups are asking for their complaints to be heard publicly, emphasizing the need to protect end-to-end encryption for privacy.

items.title: Trump family is reportedly in talks to acquire stake in Binance’s US arm
items.summary:
- President Trump's family is in discussions to invest in Binance.US, as reported by the Wall Street Journal on March 14, 2025.
- This potential investment follows Binance's U.S. arm’s guilty plea for violating anti-money laundering regulations and the CEO Changpeng Zhao's (CZ) four-month prison sentence in 2023.
- Zhao has been trying to obtain a pardon from the Trump administration, as his conviction complicates Binance's operations in the U.S. and Europe.

items.title: SoftBank buys $676M old Sharp plant for its OpenAI collab in Japan
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- SoftBank to invest $676 million in the old Sharp Sakai Plant for an AI data center.
- The factory will support generative AI operations and collaboration with OpenAI.
- Plans to begin operations in 2026, with initial power capacity of 150 megawatts, eventually increasing to over 240 megawatts.

items.title: Waymo was slapped with nearly 600 parking tickets last year in SF alone
items.summary:
- Waymo's driverless vehicles in San Francisco received 589 parking tickets last year, amounting to $65,065 in fines.
- Violations included blocking traffic, street-cleaning restrictions, and parking in prohibited areas.
- The parking ticket issuance in San Francisco is high, with approximately 1.2 million tickets given in the previous year.
- Waymo is reportedly working on addressing this parking issue, but challenges remain until all cars are driverless.

items.title: Anti-aging zealot Bryan Johnson wants to start ‘foodome sequencing’
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Bryan Johnson aims to initiate 'foodome' sequencing to analyze 20% of foods that constitute 80% of the American diet.
- His approach includes testing foods for toxins and creating a public database for accountability in food safety.
- Johnson has unconventional health practices, like blood transfusions with his son, and promotes a lifestyle aimed at extending lifespan.

items.title: Sesame, the startup behind the viral virtual assistant Maya, releases its base AI model
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AI company [Sesame](https://www.sesame.com/) releases the base model, CSM-1B, for its voice assistant Maya.
- CSM-1B has 1 billion parameters and is available under an Apache 2.0 license for commercial use.
- The model utilizes residual vector quantization (RVQ) for encoding audio, similar to technologies used by Google and Meta.
- It generates audio codes from text and has the potential for various voices but is not fine-tuned for specific ones.
- Sesame warns users against misusing the model for voice imitation or creating misleading content.
- The company, co-founded by Brendan Iribe, has recently gained popularity for its advanced assistant technologies.

items.title: Rad Power Bikes already has a new CEO
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Rad Power Bikes appoints Kathi Lentzsch as new CEO amid strategic shift.
- This change follows the resignation of previous CEO Phil Molyneux.
- The company is transitioning from a direct-to-consumer model to a retail-focused approach, leading to multiple layoffs.
- Lentzsch becomes the third CEO in three years as the company faces industry challenges similar to other e-bike brands like Cake and VanMoof.
- The shift aims to enhance customer relationships and brand evolution.

items.title: Y Combinator’s police surveillance darling Flock Safety raises $275M at $7.5B valuation
items.summary:
- Flock Safety raised $275 million at a $7.5 billion valuation, announced by Flock and Bedrock Capital.
- Founded in 2017 and a Y Combinator alum, Flock provides computer vision-enabled video surveillance used by law enforcement and businesses.
- The company has crossed $300 million in annual recurring revenue, a 70% increase year-over-year.
- Total funding for Flock exceeds $950 million with participation from notable investors like Andreessen Horowitz and GreenOaks.
- Flock has faced controversies regarding mass surveillance and privacy concerns, notably from the ACLU.
- Currently involved in a wrongful termination lawsuit initiated by a sitting mayor of a California town.

items.title: Android is adding Auracast support, which allows hearing aids to connect to public audio broadcasts
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google announced support for Auracast in Android, enabling direct connections from hearing aids to audio broadcasts.
- Compatible devices include Samsung Galaxy phones with One UI 7 and Google Pixel 9 with Android 16 beta.
- Users can personalize audio streams to their hearing with hearing aid presets.
- Pixel 9 can connect to broadcasts via QR codes, enhancing accessibility.
- Android 16 is expected to launch in June, featuring new accessibility options and Local Network Protection.

items.title: Y Combinator urges the White House to support Europe’s Digital Markets Act
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Y Combinator sent a letter to the Trump Administration urging support for Europe’s Digital Markets Act (DMA).
- The DMA aims to limit anticompetitive practices by six major tech firms: Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, ByteDance, Meta, and Microsoft.
- The act, applicable since May 2023, has already impacted American tech companies.
- YC argues the DMA aligns with American innovation values and fosters opportunities for startups in AI and consumer apps.
- The letter was signed by YC-backed startups and tech trade associations, highlighting concerns over competitive pressure in the market.
- YC claims that the DMA could open avenues for smaller ventures and mitigate Big Tech's dominance.

items.title: Oracle is reportedly a top choice for helping run TikTok
items.summary:
- TikTok has until April to finalize a sale to a U.S.-based buyer amidst uncertainties about its future.
- Oracle is reported to be the leading candidate as the cloud technology partner for TikTok in the U.S.
- Sources indicate that ByteDance prefers Oracle over other cloud providers, with Oracle already storing data for U.S. users since 2022.
- ByteDance aims to maintain a hands-on role in TikTok's operations with Oracle as a partner.
- Former President Trump has expressed support for Oracle's involvement in this deal.

items.title: Bluesky quickly sold out of the T-shirt its CEO wore to troll Mark Zuckerberg
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber wore a T-shirt with the phrase *Mundus sine Caesaribus* at SXSW, poking fun at Mark Zuckerberg without mentioning Meta.
- The shirt sold out in approximately 30 minutes after users expressed excitement on the Bluesky platform.
- Graber's shirt is a response to Zuckerberg's T-shirt that said *Aut Zuck aut nihil*, referencing comparisons made to Julius Caesar and emphasizing Bluesky's commitment to decentralization and user empowerment.

items.title: Google calls for weakened copyright and export rules in AI policy proposal
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Google submitted a policy proposal advocating for weakened copyright restrictions on AI training.
- The proposal emphasizes the necessity of "fair use" and text-and-data mining exceptions for AI development.
- It criticizes export controls imposed under the Biden Administration as burdensome for U.S. cloud service providers.
- Google calls for increased federal investment in domestic R&D and comprehensive AI legislation to clarify regulations.
- The proposal also opposes overly broad disclosure requirements and emphasizes the need to protect trade secrets.

items.title: Move over, Apple: Meet the alternative app stores coming to the EU
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA) allows access to alternative app stores.
- Developers must accept Apple's DMA-compliant terms, including a fee of €0.50 for each first annual install.
- Several alternative app stores available include AltStore PAL, Setapp Mobile, Epic Games Store, Aptoide, Mobivention, and Skich.
- Setapp Mobile, a subscription app store, offers curated apps without ads or in-app purchases, while AltStore PAL enables indie developers to distribute apps directly.
- Epic Games launched its app store allowing downloads for games like Fortnite.
- Aptoide is an open-source solution for app distribution, scanning apps for safety.

items.title: Amazon is still hosting stalkerware victims’ data weeks after breach alert
items.summary:
- Amazon is under scrutiny for hosting data from stalkerware apps despite being notified of a breach.
- Three apps, Cocospy, Spyic, and Spyzie, continue to store private phone data on Amazon Web Services.
- A security researcher indicated that the apps have exposed data from 3.1 million individuals, many of whom are unaware of the compromise.
- Amazon's response has been procedural, stating it has clear terms that require compliance with laws and policies but has not acted on the breach notifications from TechCrunch.
- The storage buckets for the apps remain active, and concerns arise about Amazon's enforcement of its own policies against spyware.

items.title: Ex-Twitter AI ethics lead Rumman Chowdhury is worried about Musk’s impact on the federal government
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Rumman Chowdhury, former director of Twitter’s machine ethics team, expressed concerns about Elon Musk's influence on U.S. governance during an SXSW panel.
- She highlighted the chaotic management style attributed to Musk and its effects on federal agencies, including significant staff cuts that may compromise cybersecurity.
- Chowdhury recalled similar experiences at Twitter after Musk's acquisition, noting that culture deteriorated under his leadership, and warned that the same could happen in government.

items.title: Minimalist Light Phone III launches March 27
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Light will launch the Light Phone III on March 27.
- Features a 3.92-inch AMOLED display, camera, and NFC chip for payments.
- The price is initially $599, increasing to $799 later.
- Offers capabilities for calls, texts, navigation, alarms, and more without distractions from apps.
- Customers can choose to use it as their main phone or a backup device to disconnect.

items.title: 10 startups to watch from Y Combinator’s W25 Demo Day
items.author: Maxwell Zeff, Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Y Combinator held its Winter 2025 Demo Day, showcasing 160 startups.
- Focus on AI agents, with many startups creating agent support tools.
- Notable startups include:
  - [Abundant](https://www.abundant.ai/): API for agent teleoperation.
  - [Browser Use](https://browser-use.com/): Tool for AI agents to navigate browsers.
  - [GradeWiz](https://www.gradewiz.ai/marketing/index.html): Automates grading with AI.
  - [Misprint](https://www.misprint.com/): Marketplace for trading Pokemon cards.
  - [Nextbyte](https://trynextbyte.com/): Helps companies find 'vibe coders' using AI.
  - [Pickle](https://getpickle.ai/): AI clone for Zoom calls.
  - [Rebolt](https://www.rebolt.ai/en): Automates restaurant management with AI.
  - [Red Barn Robotics](https://www.redbarnrobotics.com/): Weeding robot for farms.
  - [Retrofit](https://www.retrofit.shop/): AI-curated vintage clothing marketplace.
  - [Splash](https://splash9.com/): Autonomous patrol boats for defense.
- Honorable mentions: Optifye and Artificial Societies.

items.title: FBI, EPA, and Treasury told Citibank to freeze funds as Trump administration tries to claw back climate money
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Citibank revealed that the FBI, EPA, and Treasury requested freezing accounts of nonprofits and state agencies associated with the $27 billion Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund.
- The freezes took place in February, and court documents recently disclosed details, including which nonprofits are under scrutiny.
- The funding comes from the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, which allocated funds for clean technology projects, with Citibank administering the financing.
- Agencies like Habitat for Humanity and United Way have been affected, and some nonprofits have sued Citibank to unfreeze their accounts.
- EPA administrator Lee Zeldin raised concerns about fraud related to the funds without providing evidence, leading to court questioning about the legitimacy of the accusations.

items.title: Facebook now lets creators get paid for views on stories
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Facebook introduces monetization for public stories, allowing creators to earn money for views.
- The new feature is available globally to members of the [Facebook Content Monetization program](https://techcrunch.com/2024/10/02/facebook-says-it-paid-content-creators-2b-this-year/).
- Payouts are based on content performance, although specific payment details were not disclosed.
- The initiative is part of Facebook's strategy to attract creators from platforms like TikTok by offering revenue opportunities.
- Creators already in the monetization program don’t need to take additional steps to activate story monetization.
- Facebook has been successful in monetization, having paid creators over $2 billion in 2024 alone, with significant growth in payouts for Reels and other video content.

items.title: Apple’s Lockdown Mode is good for security — but its notifications are baffling
items.summary:
- Apple’s Lockdown Mode launched in 2022 aims to protect users from advanced hacking attempts, primarily benefitting dissidents, journalists, and activists.
- The feature disables certain device functionalities to minimize exposure to threats like spyware and zero-day exploits.
- User feedback reveals that notifications regarding blocked contacts are often confusing, lacking context or actionable information, raising concerns among users regarding their effectiveness.
- Examples include random notifications about blocked contacts and issues with sending certain content, like stickers, leading to uncertainty about the feature's operations.
- An experiment showed notifications appear even when messages are successfully received, suggesting limited visibility and clarity for users on what Lockdown Mode is doing.

items.title: Meghan Markle is launching a podcast about female founders
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Meghan Markle is launching a new podcast titled “Confessions of a Female Founder,” focusing on her entrepreneurial journey and conversations with other female founders.
- The podcast will premiere on April 8th on Lemonada Media and will consist of eight episodes.
- The podcast aims to share tips and experiences from successful women in business, as Meghan builds her own brand, As Ever.

items.title: OpenAI calls DeepSeek ‘state-controlled,’ calls for bans on ‘PRC-produced’ models
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI labels DeepSeek as 'state-subsidized' and suggests banning its models in a new policy proposal.
- The proposal is part of the Trump Administration’s 'AI Action Plan,' citing security risks due to Chinese compliance laws.
- OpenAI accuses DeepSeek of previously violating its terms by 'distilling' knowledge from its models.
- DeepSeek's founder met with Chinese leader Xi Jinping recently, raising concerns about Chinese government involvement.

items.title: Google wants Gemini to get to know you better
items.summary:
- Google announces Gemini with personalization as a new capability for its chatbot.
- Gemini will utilize user preferences and activities to offer tailored responses.
- The feature is currently available for web users and will gradually roll out to mobile.
- Gemini with personalization is powered by the experimental Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking AI model.
- Users will need to opt-in and must be over 18 for personalization features.
- It will also be integrated with Google Search and expand to more services like YouTube and Photos.
- Future usage limits and potential costs for the feature may apply.

items.title: Google introduces new developer tools and titles for games on mobile and PC
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Google announced new features for PC and mobile gaming ahead of the Game Developers Conference (GDC).
- New tools for developers include a dedicated SDK for native PC games and an updated Play Console.
- Google will make all mobile games available on PC by default, with an option for developers to opt out.
- New graphics API 'Vilkan' introduced for better visuals and smoother frame rates.
- New game titles announced include “Game of Thrones: Kingsroad” and “Sonic Rumble.”
- Custom control features for PC games will allow players to remap controls.
- User acquisition campaigns for mobile emulated and native PC titles will launch later this year.

items.title: Geothermal unicorn Fervo Energy may IPO as early as next year
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Fervo Energy is considering an initial public offering (IPO) within the next two years due to rising power demand from data centers.
- The company recently raised $244 million in February 2024 and another $255 million in December 2024.
- Fervo is collaborating with Google on Project Red, a geothermal power plant that can produce 3.5 megawatts of electricity for the Nevada grid.

items.title: OpenAI’s ‘creative writing’ AI evokes that annoying kid from high school fiction club
items.summary:
- OpenAI's creative writing AI resembles the archetype of an angsty teenager from high school writing workshops.
- The AI's output is critiqued for being clichéd and lacking depth, comparing phrases to pretentious teenage prose.
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman stated the AI was trained to write metafiction, a genre challenging even for human authors.
- Critics highlight that AI cannot truly experience emotions, making its introspection feel artificial.
- The AI may produce outputs that seem derivative of known authors, raising copyright and ethical concerns.
- Some educators report recognizing AI-generated work due to its homogeneity and lack of individuality.
- Users like poet Michelle Taransky try to utilize AI creatively, noting its limitations in originality and depth.
- The consensus is that while AI can mimic styles, it cannot replace the experience and learning process of human writers.

items.title: 5 ways TechCrunch Sessions: AI will fuel your AI growth
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI to take place on June 5 at Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley.
- The event aims to gather 1,200 AI experts, investors, and enthusiasts for networking and learning.
- Key discussions include what VCs want from founders and launching products against incumbents.
- Breakout sessions will allow for deeper interaction and exchange of ideas.
- The Expo Hall will showcase the latest AI technologies and innovations.
- Side Events will run from June 1-7, facilitating additional networking and insights.
- Participants can save money by registering early for the event.

items.title: Xbox debuts a new AI-powered gaming companion for mobile users
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Xbox introduced 'Copilot for Gaming', an AI-powered assistant ahead of the Game Developer's Conference (GDC).
- It can provide real-time tips, voice-activated support, and even trash talk players as needed.
- The assistant is currently available through the Xbox mobile app, designed to enhance user gaming experiences with personalized advice.

items.title: Apple’s appeal against UK’s secret iCloud backdoor order must be held in public, rights groups urge
items.summary:
- Privacy rights groups urge Apple's legal challenge against a U.K. government order for an iCloud backdoor to be public.
- The existence of the order was revealed in February 2025, prompting Apple to close its Advanced Data Protection service in the U.K.
- The Investigatory Powers Tribunal typically handles such appeals behind closed doors, but groups argue for transparency due to the case's public interest.

items.title: Spotify launches a program to publish audiobooks from independent authors
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Spotify launched a new program to publish audiobooks from independent authors, allowing submissions of short-form stories for adaptation.
- Authors will receive an advance and royalties, and stories should fall within romance, mystery, thriller, sci-fi, or fantasy genres.
- Novelettes of 10,000 to 20,000 words in English are preferred, with the requirement that authors hold audio rights to their submissions.
- This initiative aims to enhance Spotify's competition with Audible, offering authors production and distribution support.

items.title: OpenAI calls for US government to codify ‘fair use’ for AI training
items.summary:
- OpenAI proposed a U.S. copyright strategy to support AI models' use of copyrighted material in the AI Action Plan initiated by the Trump Administration.
- The company argues that the fair use doctrine is crucial for the growth of its AI startups and research breakthroughs in the U.S.
- OpenAI has previously trained models on publicly available web data without the consent of data owners, advocating for more permissive laws for AI training.

items.title: TechCrunch All Stage unveils a powerhouse agenda for founders
items.summary:
- TechCrunch All Stage returns to Boston on **July 15, 2025**.
- The agenda includes two main stages: **Foundation Stage** and **Scale Stage**.
- Foundation Stage topics include Evaluating Companies at Pre-Seed, MVP in the Age of AI, Reshaping Markets, and Crafting Pitch Decks.
- Scale Stage topics focus on Scaling Sustainable Companies, Raising for Series C and Beyond, Going Public, and Reaching $10M ARR.
- Speakers include investors and entrepreneurs from firms like Precursor Ventures, Underscore.vc, Index Ventures, NEA, DVx Ventures, and Sapphire Ventures.
- All attendees will receive transcripts and assets from presentations, with networking opportunities available.

items.title: Huawei’s lobbying lands it in a bribery scandal with EU politicians
items.summary:
- Huawei is embroiled in a scandal involving allegations of bribing members of the European Parliament (MEPs).
- The bribes aimed to secure favorable treatment from lawmakers amidst pressures against the company's telecommunications equipment in Europe.
- Belgian police conducted extensive raids as part of a corruption investigation, targeting Huawei's European offices and lobbyists' residences.
- The investigation, codenamed 'Generation', is ongoing and focuses on a two-year inquiry into bribery, forgery, and money laundering involving MEPs.

items.title: UiPath is looking for a path to growth in agentic AI with its Peak.ai acquisition
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- UiPath acquired Peak.ai, a Manchester startup specializing in decision-making AI solutions for retail and manufacturing.
- The deal was in cash, but terms were not disclosed; Peak.ai was not actively seeking a buyer.
- Peak.ai last raised funds in 2021, achieving a valuation of around $267 million and $11.6 million in revenues for 2023.
- UiPath reported a 5% revenue increase to $424 million for its fourth quarter but revised its fiscal outlook downward due to economic uncertainties.
- The acquisition is expected to enhance UiPath's offerings and cross-sell opportunities with Peak.ai's customer base.

items.title: Omni raises $69M to design tools that help companies better analyze their data
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Omni, a business intelligence platform, has raised $69 million in a Series B funding round.  
- Co-founded by Colin Zima, who previously worked at Google and Looker, Omni aims to simplify data analysis for organizations.  
- The platform enables users to conduct ad-hoc analyses and create visualizations, with a user-friendly interface.  
- Omni serves over 200 companies, with expectations of tripling its annual recurring revenue to nearly $30 million this year.  
- The latest funding will enhance its analytics capabilities and support hiring efforts to expand its team from 85 to 150 employees.  
- Omni has now raised a total of $97 million, boasting a $650 million valuation.

items.title: Skich launches an alternative app store on iOS in the EU
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Skich has launched a new mobile games marketplace for iOS users in the EU, challenging established stores like Epic Games and Aptoide.
- The Skich Store will start adding games at the end of March, post Game Developers Conference.
- This move aligns with the EU's Digital Markets Act, which facilitates competition by allowing third-party app stores on iOS.
- The store incorporates social features like game swiping, playlists, and an activity feed for friends' gameplay.
- Skich will charge a 15% commission, compared to Apple's 30% cut, potentially making it more attractive for developers.
- The current Skich web platform has about 100,000 organic monthly visitors, and the store will replace the existing app soon.
- An Android version of the Skich Store is planned for launch in May.

items.title: ClickUp is launching a revamped calendar tool for task and meeting management
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- ClickUp has launched a revamped calendar tool that integrates tasks, documents, chats, and meetings.
- New features include an AI meeting notetaker and AI-powered time blocking based on user schedules.
- The calendar adjusts due dates dynamically and allows for manual task adjustments.
- The AI notetaker can take notes, transcribe meetings, and assign tasks automatically.
- 71% of survey respondents are comfortable sending an AI proxy to meetings.
- ClickUp aims to be an all-in-one productivity platform, expanding beyond task and project management.

items.title: Meta is launching Community Notes in the US next week
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Meta will launch Community Notes in the US on March 18 for Facebook, Instagram, and Threads users.
- The feature is a crowdsourced fact-checking system similar to Twitter's introduced in 2021.
- The initial rollout is focused on the US to address concerns over bias and misinformation, with plans for international expansion uncertain due to investigations in the EU.
- The initiative is part of Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg's effort to address public perception of bias.
- Community Notes aims to improve trust by allowing contributors to suggest notes and rate their usefulness, focusing on consensus from opposing viewpoints.
- Prior studies suggest Community Notes can effectively reduce the spread of misinformation, but issues with speed and reach remain.

items.title: Singapore grants bail for Nvidia chip smugglers in alleged $390M fraud
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- A judge in Singapore granted bail to three men accused of deceiving suppliers regarding Nvidia chips under U.S. export restrictions.
- The alleged fraud involves server transactions amounting to approximately $390 million, with connections to companies like Dell and Super Micro.
- The bail amounts were S$800,000, S$600,000 for the two Singaporean men and S$1 million for the Chinese national; conditions include electronic monitoring and restrictions on travel and communication about the case.
- Next court hearing scheduled for May 2, following requests from prosecution for eight weeks to conclude investigations.
- Malaysia plans to take action against local companies involved in the alleged fraud.

items.title: Bria lands new funding for AI models trained on licensed data
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Bria, founded in 2023 by Yair Adato and Assa Eldar, focuses on training AI image generators with licensed content.
- The company has raised $40 million in a Series B round, increasing total funding to $65 million.
- Bria plans to use funds for product development and aims to expand its offerings to include various media types beyond images.

items.title: Telegram introduces trading and yield features for its self-custodial crypto wallet
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Telegram's crypto wallet now offers multi-asset trading and yield functionalities.
- Launched in 2023 by The Open Platform, the wallet supports Toncoin, Bitcoin, and USDT.
- The update allows users to buy/sell/hold crypto without on-chain deposits.
- A new earning component for Toncoin holders and upcoming support for USDT yields is planned.
- The user interface has been improved with a new navigation bar for Wallet, Trade, and Earn sections.
- The update will be rolled out in March and April 2025, with potential restrictions based on local regulations.
- Telegram has over 100 million users registered for the wallet, many of whom are new to cryptocurrency.

items.title: Could deeptech serve as Europe’s path to autonomy from the US?
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- A report suggests that deeptech could be crucial for Europe’s security and autonomy from the US amidst geopolitical tensions.
- In 2024, deeptech attracted €15 billion ($16.3 billion) in venture investments, making up nearly one-third of all VC investment in Europe.
- The M&A activity in deeptech reached $12.2 billion, yet European startups still depend on the US for exits and 50% of their growth capital comes from outside Europe.
- Co-author Lukas Leitner emphasizes the need for Europe to embrace deeptech to achieve resilience despite challenges.
- The US deeptech scene benefits from a “flywheel effect,” while Europe’s ecosystem is still developing.
- Europe shows promise in photonics computing and could attract scientists from the US due to budget cuts in American science funding.

items.title: Xiaomi to preinstall PhonePe’s app store on smartphones sold in India
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Xiaomi will preinstall PhonePe’s Indus Appstore on its Android smartphones sold in India, replacing GetApps.
- The deal with PhonePe is a multi-year agreement; Google’s Play Store will remain preinstalled.
- Indus Appstore supports 12 Indian languages and features over 500,000 apps; it aims to compete with Google without charging developers for in-app purchases.
- The roll-out details for existing devices and implementation dates are currently unspecified.
- Xiaomi’s COO emphasized the importance of a locally driven app marketplace for India’s digital growth.
